title: Widen Your Options
summary: Avoid narrow framing by generating more choices before making a decision.

details.content: When we focus too narrowly on a single option, we miss out on better alternatives and creative solutions. Expanding options leads to more informed and effective decisions.
Instead of asking, 'Should I take this job offer or not?', consider, 'What other roles or companies could I explore? Are there ways to negotiate this offer or create new opportunities?'

content: Ask yourself, 'What else could I do?' before deciding.
Consider the 'AND' option instead of 'OR'—can you combine choices?
Seek input from others to uncover overlooked alternatives.
Imagine you can't choose your current options—what would you do then?

title: Reality-Test Your Assumptions
summary: Challenge your beliefs and gather real-world evidence before committing to a decision.

details.content: We often seek information that confirms our existing beliefs, leading to biased decisions. Testing assumptions helps uncover blind spots and reduces overconfidence.
If you assume a new product will succeed, talk to potential customers, run small experiments, or seek disconfirming evidence before investing heavily.

content: Ask, 'What would convince me that I'm wrong?'
Run small tests or pilots to gather data.
Seek out people with opposing viewpoints.
Use the 'vanishing options' test: If your current choice disappeared, what would you do?

title: Attain Distance Before Deciding
summary: Step back emotionally and gain perspective to make more objective decisions.

details.content: Emotions and short-term pressures can cloud judgment. Gaining distance helps you focus on long-term goals and values.
When facing a tough personnel decision, ask yourself, 'What would I advise my best friend to do in this situation?'

content: Sleep on important decisions to reduce emotional bias.
Ask, 'What will I think about this choice in 10 minutes, 10 months, and 10 years?'
Imagine advising someone else in your situation.
Clarify your core priorities before deciding.

title: Prepare to Be Wrong
summary: Plan for possible failures and setbacks to increase resilience and adaptability.

details.content: We tend to be overconfident about our predictions. Anticipating what could go wrong helps us create safeguards and respond effectively to surprises.
Before launching a new project, identify possible obstacles and create contingency plans for each.

content: Conduct a 'premortem': Imagine your decision failed—why did it happen?
Set tripwires or checkpoints to monitor progress and trigger reassessment.
List possible risks and how you would respond.
Accept that mistakes are part of the process and plan to learn from them.
